review: I like the overall idea of the Fire TV Stick (in the past we used our PS3 to access Amazon Prime on our TV) But I am kinda bummed that there is a power cord that plugs into the stick.  I thought the whole point was the portability of the whole thing, and here I am tracing down power cords once more whenever I want to move from one TV to another.  In addition, our main TV only has HDMI ports on the back side, and Amazon solved that problem by providing an HDMI extender cable, but the extender cable is only a few inches long, so it really didn't solve much of anything.  In short, the idea is good, but I am just not seeing much benefit to using it over our PS3.

review: This is the sixth streaming device that I've used.  That includes four Roku boxes and a Chromecast stick that I took a sledge hammer to.  The Fire stick is the cheapest and the best.The picture is better than the Roku 3 box when you compare them at 1080p resolution.  When I tested it while watching "House of Cards", which is also 1080p, the Fire gave as good a picture as my up converting smart Blu-ray player.  I do recommend using the power supply that comes with the stick, even though I was also able to power it from the USB port on my TV.  The Amazon power supply gives a brighter and more reliable picture and will not drop out during system updates should you accidentally power off the TV.The wireless connection is robust and works even when your SSID is not being broadcast (unlike Chromecast).  Setup was easy/  The app selection is not as broad as Roku but I could access 90% of the channels that I actually watch on the Roku.  I think with the momentum that Amazon has these days, the choices will be identical in a year.The unit mirrors seamlessly to my Kindle Fire HDX tablet.  If you are a Prime member, then there is NO reason not to have a Fire TV device.  In fact, get one to just keep in your travel kit to use in hotels.Well done Amazon.  This was my least expensive and most enjoyable Christmas present.
